for stealing 1 coat, value 3l. 10s.; 8 pairs of trowsers, 5l. 15s.; 6 waistcoats, 1l. 14s.; 2 shirts, 5s.; 3 printed books, 5s.; 2 table-cloths, 17s.; and 1 pair of boots, 1l.; the goods of
George Wentworth Forbes, his master.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

1189.
MADELINE STEWART was indicted
for stealing 1 handler
chief, value 2s. the goods of
Thomas Rix.

JOHN WILSON PARKER . I am apprentice to Thomas Rix, of Woolwich. On the 3rd of May, the prisoner came to the shop for some blond—she took a handkerchief off the counter, put it under her arm, and walked out with it—I fetched her back with the handkerchief under her arm—she said she had asked me about the handkerchief, and then she said she had paid for it, but she had not,
Prisoner. Did I not buy some blond and some ribbon, and give you a sovereign: and why did you give me only 18s. if I had not bought the handkerchief? the policeman only took 18s. from me.

Witness. She bought three yards of blond at 1d. a yard, and one yard of ribbon at 2d.—she gave me a sovereign—I gave her 19s. 6d. and 1d.—I gave her full change all but 5d.—I cannot remember what coin I gave her.
GEORGE KELLY (police-constable R 167.) I took the prisoner—she had a half-sovereign and 18s. in her hand—she bad no sixpence and no penny.
NOT GUILTY .

1190.
WILLIAM JENKINS and
HENRY JOSEPH FINCH were indicted for
stealing from the person of
John Mark 1 purse, value 6d.; 12 sovereigns, 6 half-sovereigns, and 1 10l. bank-note, his property; and that Finch had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN MARK . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery, at Woolwich. On the 28th of April I had been to London—I had a 30l. bank-note, which I changed at Mr. Crump's, in Goswell-road—I received for it a 10l. banknote and sovereigns, half-sovereigns, and silver—I put the note and money in my purse into my watch-pocket—I did not take the number of the note, but I observed some writing on it which enables me to know it again—I then went to Dalston, and from there to London-bridge, to get back to Woolwich—it was then past eleven o'clock at night, I dare say—I was perfectly sober—I went to a stand of cabs and called for one—Jenkins came up as the driver, and brought the cab to the curb-stone—I asked what he would take me to Woolwich for—he said 8s.—I said I could not afford that, and offered him 2s.—he said he could not take me for 2s.—Finch was standing near him, and he said, "O take the gentleman down, take him down for 2s., he will likely stand a pot of ale on the road"—that was the first I had seen of Finch—Jenkins said very well, he would do

it—I got in, and Jenkins said, "Will you allow this man (meaning Finch) to go with you as far as Greenwich in the cab?"—Finch was by at the time—I said, "Yes, you may get in," and he got in—the cab went on between half and two-thirds of the way between London and Greenwich, and it there stopped—Finch said, "Draw up here," or "We had better stop here"—Jenkins drew up by a public-house on the left hand side—Finch got out on the right side of the cab, went round, and went into the public-house, and, as I presume, got a pot of ale—I paid for it—I did not get out, and cannot say whether Jenkins was on his box or not—Finch was away five or six minutes—he then came to the left side of the cab and said to me, "Here, take a glass of this ale"—I said, "Is it good?"—he said, "Yes, very good"—I drank it and gave him the glass, which he took into the house again, then came and took his seat in the cab—I then fell asleep, and did not awake till we got to Woolwich—I was still asleep, Jenkins came and awoke me up, and said, "You are at Woolwich"—Finch was then gone—I said, "Very well"—I got out of the cab, and found Jenkins in the act of getting on the box again, never having asked me for his money—I said, "Oh! I have not paid you, I must pay you"—I went to feel for my money, and found my purse and money were gone—I said, "Good G—! I have been robbed; you know something about it; where is the man that you asked my permission to let ride with me?"—I seized hold of Jenkins and said, "I will detain you until I give you in charge"—two policemen came up—I gave him, his horse and cab, in charge—I have seen the 10l. note since, and identified it—this is it—here is the word "York" upon it—when we arrived at the station I gave so minute a description of Finch that he was taken the next day.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What had you been doing that day? A. I had got leave from my commanding officer to come to town on Sunday the day before—I went to No. 21, St. James-street—the persons I went to see were not at home, and on the Monday morning I called there again—I had dined at four o'clock in the afternoon—I had a mutton-chop and a glass of porter—I took about three glasses of port wine within two hours after my dinner—I had about a couple more glasses between eight and nine o'clock, which made five glasses after my dinner—I took nothing else till I had the ale in the cab—it was, past eleven when I got into the cab.

Jenkins. Q. Was you sober, or was you not? A. I have sworn I was sober—when I came to you at London-bridge, you brought your cab to the curb—I swear I had only one glass of ale on the road, which was at the first house you stopped at—whether you stopped at any other house after I lost my senses I cannot tell.

WILLIAM CRUMP . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Goswell-street-road—the prosecutor came to my house on Monday evening, the 28th of April—I changed a 30l. note for him—I gave him this 10l. note, and the rest in gold and silver—here is my writing on the note, and I had pre
viously taken the number of it, whrch I have here—the prosecutor was quite sober then—here is the name of the person I took the note from on it.

MICHAEL GARVEY (police-constable R 87.) I was on duty on Tuesday morning, the 29th of April—I took Jenkins from the prosecutor, and took him to the station—the prosecutor accused him, and said, "Where is the man that was in the cab along with me?"—Jenkins said, "I do not know, I put him down at Greenwich, I have no knowledge of him"—this was in
Church-street, Woolwich, before we started for the station—when we got there Jenkins said he had seen the person who was in the cab before, and he should know him again if we were to see him.

THOMAS BALDWIN (police-sergeant L 13.) I was in the Westminster-road, at half-past six o'clock on Tuesday morning, the 29th of April—I went into the Oxford Arms, and saw Finch, in company with some men, three of whom were cab men—Finch was treating them, and I saw him take some money out of his right-hand pocket—I saw him count seven sove
reigns and some silver—I told him he had better take care of his money—he said it was all right, they were all his men, and he was treating them.

JAMES CUDDY (police-sergeant L 20.) I had heard a description of Finch—I went to Batty's Theatre on Tuesday evening, the 29th of April, and found Finch in the gallery—I took him into custody—I found on him this 10l. note, 1l. 11s. 2d. in silver, and 5d. in copper.

Jenkins's Defence. On the 28th the soldier hired my cab, he was with another party, and each of them were smoking cigars; he asked what I would take him for, I said 8s.; he said he could not afford that, he would give me 2s.; we hesitated some minutes, and then I agreed to take him for 2s.; the cab was not drawn down; he said he would give me some ale on the road; we stopped at three places; he drank two or three glasses of ale; I stopped once in Tooley-street, once at Mill pond-bridge, and once further on; I got to Woolwich, and he was asleep; I said, "This is Woolwich;" he said, "Where is the man?" I said he got out at Green-wich; the policeman came up; I told him the circumstance, and he said to the prosecutor, "Will you give the prisoner in charge?" he said "Yes;" I have witnesses to prove he was intoxicated when he took my cab,

WILLIAM COCKRILL (police-constable L 108.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Finch's former conviction, which I got at Kingston-upon-Thames—(read—Convicted 28th Dec. 1833, and confined three months, and whipped)—the prisoner is the person.

JENKINS—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Ten Years.

FINCH—
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1191.
PHILIP SHARPE was indicted
for stealing 1 writing-desk, value 5s.; 1 breast-pin, 2s. 6d.; 1 watch-key, 6d.; 1 medal, 2s. 6d.; and 1 printed book, 1s.; the goods of
John Fiddes.

JOSEPH FLEMMING . I am steward on board the sloop of war Alecto, which is in Woolwich Dockyard. On the 25th of April I was ordered to remove John Fiddes's clothes and goods from that vessel to the Ship tavern—I got the prisoner and others to assist me—amongst other things there was a desk, a breast-pin, and a watch-key—I afterwards missed the desk—this is it.
NICHOLAS MOULD . I keep a public-house at Woolwich. On the 25th of April, between two and three o'clock, the prisoner brought this desk to my house, and asked me to let him put it down a few minutes.
GEORGE GURNEY (police-constable R 303.) I took the prisoner—I found this watch-key and breast-pin upon him.

JOSEPH FLEMMING
re-examined. This breast-pin belongs to John Fiddes.
Prisoner's Defence. I was standing at the Dock-gate; this gentleman came and asked me if I would have a job; he took me and some others
down into the cabin, and made us nearly drunk; the things were put into a cart; the men broke the cart, and the things all rolled about; I took the desk into the public-house, and forgot it again.
JOSEPH FLEMMING . I did not make them drunk—I gave them a small drop of rum after the job was over—the prisoner got drunk afterwards.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1192.
WILLIAM GRACE was indicted
for stealing 1 gelding, price 6l., the property of
William Newett, his master.

WILLIAM NEWETT . I am a carman, and live in Shooter's Hul-road—the prisoner was in my service. On Friday morning, the 4th of April, I gave him a gelding, and told him to go to the Catherine Wheel inn with it, and to see the ostler, who would direct him to where I had the gelding from—I had bought it, but did not like it, and wanted to return it—he was to take it to the man, and if he did not take it in, he was to take it back to the ostler at the Catherine Wheel—I saw the prisoner again on the Sunday morning—he said he had left the horse all right at Mr. Adams's, the man I had it of—I said, "Very well"—I had changed another horse away, and was to give 8l. for this one, but it was not sound, and I returned it.

GEORGE HOOK . I am ostler at the Catherine Wheel in the Borough. On Friday morning, 4th of April, about ten o'clock, the prisoner came with a hone—he asked if I knew it—I said "No," hut I looked again, and said I did—he asked if I knew where Mr. Adams lived—I said yes, about 300 yards from the Catherine Wheel, the second public-house on the right hand—he said he should go with tire horse there, and return and give me an answer about it, but he did not return.

Prisoner. There was no such words; I said I was to leave the horse with a man named Hook; I said to him, "You take it in and keep it a week till my master comes;" he said he could not take it in; he directed me out of the yard; I had no name or number to go to. Witness. No, he told me he would go with the horse, and I said if he could not find the man to come back to me again.

THOMAS MOOR . I am foreman to Mr. Giddings, a horse-slaughter. The prisoner came to me that morning to sell the horse, as he, said, for the best price he could get for it—it was a glandered horse, and unfit to be about—I paid him 2l. for it, and he gave me a receipt.

Prisoner's Defence. My master came, and gave me 3s. which was all I received of him for three weeks; he sent me to the place with the hocse, and if I could not get rid of it there I was to sell it, and to bring the money home; these were the last words he said to me; the ostler refused taking it in, as it was glandered; he said it was more than his place was worth; my master told me I was to take it to this man, and he had better have the money he could get for it, than nothing.

WILLIAM NEWETT
re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner tell you he had sold it, and give you the 2l.? A. No—he said he left it at Mr. Adah's, and tied it up in the stable—I did not know the horse was glandered, but it was not sound, and would not do for me.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Year.

1193.
SARAH ANN ADAMS was indicted
for stealing 2 half-crowns the monies of
William White, from his person.

WILLIAM WHITE . I am a shipwright. On the 20th of April I was at a public-house in Woolwich—the prisoner was by my side—I had 10s., when I went in—I sat there, and had two or three pints of beer—I did not know what I did altogether, but a gentleman called me out, and asked if I had been robbed—I found I had lost two half-crowns from my right band pocket.
Prisoner. At the Duke on Horseback you gave me two half-crowns to go with you. Witness. I did not.

JOHN M'DONALD . I was at the Duke on Horseback, between ten and eleven o'clock at night, on the 20th of April—I saw the prisoner come in with the prosecutor—she asked him for 1s., which he gave her, and no sooner bad he done that than she put her hand into his right hand pocket, and took out two half-crowns, put them to her hair, and then put then into her mouth—I went to her, and said, "Do you chew tobacco?"—she said "Yes"—I said, "You had better put that quid out of your mouth"—she went out—I followed, and gave her in charge.

JOHN WALLEN (police-constable R 298.) I took the prisoner—she de
nied having any money, and all knowledge of it—I took her hand, and had a violent struggle with her—I at last got two half-crowns from her.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the 5s.; M'Donald wanted me to give half a crown to spend, and I would not.

GUILTY .** Aged 28.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(John Wallen stated that the prisoner had been thirty-two times in custody.)

1194.
MARGARET SKELDING was indicted
for stealing 2 waist-coats, value 6s., the goods of
John Daniel Delaney.

WILLIAM LEACH . I am shopman to John Daniel Delaney, pawnbroker, High-street, Woolwich. On the 3rd of May I missed this satin waistcoat, which I had seen half an hour before hanging in the shop—I know nothing of the prisoner.

GEORGE STEVENS . I am shopman to Messrs. Davis, pawnbroker, Woolwich. The prisoner came there on the 3rd of May, between seven and eight o'clock—she asked me 5s. on two waistcoats, and gave the name of Ann Murphy—I recollect her, as there was a gown hanging there, which she took down, and took it away with her—these are the two waist-coats she brought—her husband brought the gown back to me.

WILLIAM LEACH
re-examined. These waistcoats are Mr. Delaney's.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 122.) I took the prisoner on Monday, the 5th of May, at her own home—I told her what she was charged with—she said it was not her, she knew nothing about it—I said, "I saw you at Mr. Delaney's shop on Saturday evening"—she said, "Yes, I was there, I went to redeem my husband's trowsers"—she gave me up ten duplicates, but they relate to her own property, I believe.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

1195.
WILLIAM CUMMINGS and
THOMAS BROWN
were in
dicted for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of Peter Dow, from his person.
PETER DOW . I am a teacher, and live at Lee Park, Blackheath. On the 12th of May I was in Greenwich fair—I had my handkerchief safe—I did not miss it till I was touched on the shoulder—this is it

WILLIAM NORTON . I am a tailor, and live at Deptford. I was at Green-wich fair on the afternoon of the 12th of May—I saw the two prisoners behind the prosecutor—I saw Brown take this handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket, and hand it to Cummings—I informed the prosecutor of it, and held the prisoners till the officer came up—in the mean time Cummings dropped the handkerchief, and the prosecutor picked it up.
JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190) I saw the prisoners at the fair attempting to pick pockets on several occasions—I took them into custody—Cummings ried to escape, but I took him.
Cummings's Defence. I was looking at a show, and some boy threw a handkerchief at me.
Brown's Defence. I was standing by the side of the prosecutor; the witness took hold of me.

CUMMINGS—
GUILTY . Aged 13.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 11.

1196.
JOHN EDWARDS was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
George Wintle Roberts, from his person.

GEORGE WINTLE ROBERTS . I live in Park-street, Islington. On the 14th of May I was at Greenwich fair, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening—I lost my handkerchief, which I had had safe about half a minute before—the moment I lost it the officer inquired of me if I had lost it.

JAMES RAPSEY (police-constable R 102.) I saw the prisoner at the fair try a great many pockets—he went behind Mr. Roberts, and closed behind him—in half a minute he turned away—I spoke to Mr. Roberts, then turned and apprehended the prisoner—he had this handkerchief.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw the handkerchief under my feet; I picked it up, got on the foot-path, and the policeman collared me.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1197.
MICHAEL MAROONEY and
ANDREW MANYON were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Berridge, from his person; to which

MANYON pleaded
GUILTY .* Aged 13.—
Confined Six Months.

CHARLES BERRIDOE . I am a coal-merchant, and live in Vauxhall-street. On the 12th of May, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, I was in Greenwich fair—an officer touched me on the shoulder, and I found that I had lost two handkerchiefs—the one that was found on the prisoner Manyon I had wiped my face with a few minutes before—this is the same pattern as the one I had—I do not know it by any mark—I have every reason to believe it is mine.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) I was in Greenwich fair—I saw the two prisoners in company—they went and closed behind the prosecutor, and I saw Manyon lift the tail of his coat—I did not see them take the handkerchief, but I suspected them, and spoke to the prosecutor

—he said he had lost something—I went and took the prisoner—Manvon I said, "I have stolen the gentleman's handkerchief"—he put his hand into the flap of his trowsers, and took out this handkerchief—the prosecutor said, "That is not mine"—I took the prisoners to the station, and I fonud in Manyon's waistcoat this other handkerchief, which the prosecutor does identify.
HENRY JORDAN . I am a butcher. I was at the fair—I saw Manyon feel the prosecutor's coat-tail pocket—Marooney was standing by his side.
Marooney's Defence. I did not know this boy, only I thought I had seen him; I asked if he lived in such a place, and if he was going home; that was all I said to him.

MAROONEY—
NOT GUILTY .

1198.
JOHN SULLIVAN and
BRIDGET COLLINS were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d. the goods of
George Stone, from his person; to which

SULLIVAN* pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.

GEORGE STONE . I live in South-street, Greenwich. On the 14th of May I was in Greenwich fair—some one spoke to me—I turned, and saw my handkerchief in Sullivan's hand—this is it—I should think I had had it safe half an hour before—I laid hold of Sullivan—the officer made a snatch at the same time, and he got the handkerchief.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) On the 14th of May, I was at Greenwich—I saw the prisoners together—I watched them for half an hour—I saw Sullivan go behind several gentlemen, followed by Collins, who spread out her gown, while Sullivan felt their pockets—I then saw Sullivan go behind the prosecutor—Collins was close behind him, and spread out her gown to hide him from view—I saw Sullivan take the hand
kerchief—he was in the act of giving it to Collins at the time I took it from him.
Collins's Defence. I never saw it.

COLLINS—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: SURREY CASES.

div1.p:
1199.
JOHN VOSPER was indicted
for stealing 5 pairs of boots, value 18s., the goods of
James Berry, his master.

JAMES BERRY . I am a shoemaker, and live at Southwark. The pri
soner was my journeyman for about twelve months, and lodged in the house—my workshop is on the second floor—on the 9th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, he asked me to sell him a candle, knowing I was busy, he said he wished to do as much work as possible in that week, and he would work late, or all that night—I allowed Mrs. Berry to let him have a candle—I went to rest—he went up to the work-shop—he slept in the house, and could retire when he thought proper—next morning I found he was gone, with another, who has not been taken since—five pairs of boots were also gone, part his own work, and part another workman's—I have since seen three pairs of the boots, but not the other two.

ROBERT DOUTHWAITE . I am a boot and shoemaker, and live in Tot
hill-street, Westminster. On the 10th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock the prisoner came to my shop in company with another—he showed line two pairs of boots, and asked if I would purchase them—I asked where he got them—he said they were his own goods, and he was on the fuddle—I offered him 5s. for them, which was the full value—they were not new, and had been repaired—he went away for half an hour, or three quar
ters of an hour, returned, and said he would take the 5s.—I produce the boots—he promised to return in an hour or two with some more—I had not bought them above half an hour, when Mr. Berry came and identified them—next morning a man came with these for sale—Mr. Berry said they were his, and if the man came, I was to detain him—he came again—I looked outside, and saw the prisoner down below—I immediately sent for a constable and had him apprehended.

Prisoner. I sold the two pairs of boots, but the other man received the money. Witness. No, you did—I gave you two half-crowns, and you said, "We will go and have a drop of beer, as we are on the fuddle" these are the boots.
JAMES BARNICOATT (police-constable P 149.) The prisoner and another were given into my custody—I received these two pairs of boots at the station, from the inspector on duty.
Prisoner's Defence. I pleaded guilty to that small pair as soon as I was taken into custody; I said it was my work, but I know nothing of the others; they are the other man's.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1200.
WILLIAM FREDERICK COX was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 10th of May, at Richmond, a forged re
ceipt for the payment of 4l. 19s. 1d., with intent to defraud
William Smith.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be with intent to defraud the
vestrymen of Richmond; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Two Years without hard labour, being ill.

1201.
WILLIAM ROBERTS was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Scarborough, about twelve in the night of the 18th of April, at Camber well, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, I cruet-stand, value 3l. 10s.; 2 cruet-tops, 8s.; 2 knife-rests, 4s.; 1 spoon, 5s.; 1 neckerchief, 7s.; 8 trays, 3s.; 2 pence, 10 half-pence, and 12 farthings; his property.

THOMAS SCARBOROUGH . I live in Sussex-place, Kent-road, in the pa
rish of Camberwell—I rent the house. On Friday night, the 18th of April, I went to bed at ten o'clock—my house was quite safe—the back parlour window and all the others were fastened at the top with a bolt—I saw they were all fast—next morning, between seven and eight, I found I could not get into the room—the bolt was shot inside—I had to go into the yard to get in at the window, which is nine or ten feet from the ground—I then found the window open—the spring was broken—I found all my silver gone off the sideboard—it was safe at ten o'clock the night before—the cruet-stand produced is mine, and was left in that room that night—here are four table-spoons, one gravy-spoon, a mustard-spoon, and the tops of the cruets—they all belong to me—the glasses are gone—a box, in which my wife
kept her accounts and money, was broken open, and thrown into a ditch at the back of the house—I lost property worth 10l. altogether.

DANIEL HALEY (policeman.) On the morning of the 19th of April I was on duty in the Kent-road, about a mile and a quarter from the prosecu
tor's, and about one o'clock I saw the prisoner, and stopped him, as my brother constable, who was on the other side, challenged him, and said, "Jessey, what do you do out at this time?"—he said, "I have been at a raffle for a handkerchief, and won it"—I said, "What have you in your pocket?"—he said, "Some keys"—the constable said, "Pull them out," which he did—I said, "What have you got in your trowsers?"—he said, "Nothing"—I undid his flap, and found this cruet-stand in his trowsers, and these cruet-tops in his right-hand pocket—these keys, knife-rests, handkerchief, and money, were found on him—he said he found the pro
perty in a garden in the Old Kent-road.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ever know me charged before? A. You have been before a Magistrate several times, but nothing was brought clear against you.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to a raffle; I left about half-past tweln o'clock, and in the New Kent-road I saw the things in the garden; I reached over, and put them into my pocket; there was another chap witl me; he said, "We will take them home."

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Ten Years. Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

1202.
THOMAS BLUNDELL, alias Smith
,
JEMIMA WILSON, alias Smith
, and
ANN WILSON , were indicted for
feloniously, knowingly, and without lawful excuse, having in their custody and possession two moulds, intended for counterfeiting penny pieces.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 83.) On Sunday, the 20th of April, between one and two o'clock, I saw the prisoners Blundell and Jemima Wilson at the station-house, and, while there, I saw Blundell put something into his mouth, which he appeared to swallow with great diffi
culty—I said they should be searched—the female prisoner was taken to the back of the station-house by the female searcher, who after
wards returned, and said Jemima Wilson had two keys which she refused to give up—I said they would be taken from her if she did not—she then produced them—I went to No. 10, Eaton-street, New-cut, Black-friars-road, with Romain, a constable, and there found the prisoner Ann lying on the floor between the bedstead and cupboard—as we went into the room Romain turned his light on—she looked up, and said, "I thought it was my sister come," and asked where she was—I said, "She is locked up at the station, you had better get up and dress your
self"—Romain took a candle off the bedstead, and lighted it—I saw something white in the cupboard, and found a mould there, which I produce—I found a file on the same shelf, five counterfeit penny pieces, and this bag, with "Robson, plaster-of-Paris manufacturer, Mount-pleasant," on it—I found some pieces of metal in the cupboard called gets, which fit the mould, and some pieces of run metal among the cinders under the fire-place—I found some more pieces of plaster-of-Paris between the stove and the wall—there were small splashes of white metal in the front of the stove, and about the bars—I said to Ann Wilson, "I have found a mould and several counterfeit coins here, you must go to the station"—she said,

"I do not live here, it is my sister's room; I live at No. 12, and will show you"—I tried the keys to the door, and found both of them locked and un
locked the room door—it was not fastened when I went in—I asked Ann how she got in—she said she burst the door open to lie down, as her sister was out—I went with her to No. 12—she pointed out the back, parlour on the ground floor as her room—as we went in she said something I did not understand, but she seemed surprised that there was no furniture there—the room was empty—I examined the fire-place, and behind it and under it, in the ashes, I found these pieces of plaster-of-Paris, which appear like broken moulds—the floor before the hearth was loose—I took up four boards, went under the flooring, and found this broken pipkin, which appears to have burst on the fire, as the metal appears to have flown from it—there are portions of metal in it—I found other pieces of plaster-of-Paris under the floor—as I was tying them up, Ann said, "I know nothing of them"—I found one key locked and unlocked the door of No. 12, but not the other.

WILLIAM ROMAIN (policeman.) I accompanied the witness on the 20th of April, shortly after one o'clock in the morning—the door was shut—we shoved against it, and it went open—we went up to the first floor back room—the door was shut but not fastened—it had been burst open—Ann Wilson said she did not live there, she had burst the door open to get in to sleep—I found on the mantle-piece this mould, some blue-stone, and in the cupboard a saucer, with some lead-pipe, and a piece of broken mould—this shovel was on the coals at the bottom of the cupboard, with this metal in it—here are marks at the back as if it had been on the fire—we went to No. 12 with Ann Wilson—she said that was the room she rented, but she had moved her things out the previous day—next day I accompanied the prisoners to the Magistrate—Ann said on the road, all the trouble she had got into, Blundell and her sister had brought her into—this was not in the other prisoners' hearing.

HONORA HANCOCK . I am the wife of Thomas Hancock, of No. 10, Eaton-street—my huband rents Nos. 10 and 12—the female prisoners came to me nine weeks before they were taken—Ann took the room, No. 12, and the other No. 10, where I live—Blundell was not with them then—Jemima took the room at No. 10 for herself and husband, who she said was a baker's man—I gave her the key, and in three days after he came to live there—I saw him up and down, coming to and fro, as a man would do at his own place—I saw Ann Wilson at No. 10, coming in and out to the other prisoners' room—she occupied my room at No. 12 for nine weeks before she was apprehended—they were not both taken at the same time—Jemima took No. 10 four weeks after Ann took No. 12—they both came together to take No. 12, and about four weeks after Jemima took No. 10—Ann paid the rent of 12, and Jemima of No. 10, but the last time the man paid 9d. which, he said, was on account of rent—I gave the key of No. 12 to Ann, and that of No. 10 to Jemima—I thought Ann slept at No. 12, but do not know whether there was a bed there.

Blundell Q. When did I pay you the last money? A. The very day you was taken, about four o'clock on Saturday evening—I did not see you go out at the time, and cannot recollect whether you had your things on to go out.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint—this plaster-of-Paris mould, found at No. 10, is intended, and has been used, to cast counterfeit penny pieces, and has impressions of both sides of a penny

piece—here are five counterfeit penny pieces which have been cast in it three of them have the gets attached to them—I have applied them to the mould and they fit it—they would have to be colpured by means of a solu
tion of sulphate of copper before they are circulated—a pair of scissors is generally used to remove the gets, and, afterwards, a file to take off the surplus metal—here is a file with white metal in the teeth of it, and some pieces of white metal similar to the counterfeit coin, several of them in the forms of gets—here is some plaster-of-Paris which appears to have been a mould, but has no impression on it now—here is a mould found at No. 12 with the impression of both sides of a farthing on it—here is some white metal, lead and pewter, similar to the metal in the shovel—I believe the coins to be Britannia metal and pewter—I cannot tell exactly—the metal in the shovel appears of a similar description, and to have been fused in this shovel—here is a pipkin which appears to have been used to fuse in white metal, and some broken pieces of plaster without any impressions upon them—they appear to be parts of moulds.

(Blundell put in a written defence stating, that he left his room on the morn
ing in question and met a man named Willis and his wife, who asked per
mission to stop in his room till the evening, that he gave them the key, that ht staid out late, and never returned home, being taken into custody for an as
sault, and he had no knowledge of the things being there.)

BLUNDELL—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

JEMIMA WILSON—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

ANN WILSON—
NOT GUILTY .

1203.
MARY WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, at Lambeth, 2 purses, value 3s.; 1 ring, 10s.; 1 brooch, 1s.; 2 card counters, 10s.; 2 Bank tokens, 10s.; 2 guineas; 46 sovereigns; 1 half-sovereign; 5 sixpences; 5 pence; 7 halfpence; and 1 £5 Bank-note, the goods and monies of
Sarah Caroline Edmonds, her mistress, in her dwelling-house; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1204.
RICHARD BAKER. alias George Underwood
, was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Fanny Stewart, about the hour of eleven in the night of the 4th of May, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 22 gold rings, value 4l. 8s.; 7 silver watches, 8l.; 2 caddy spoons and 6 tea-spoons, 12s.; 3 sugar-tongs, 15s.; 1 child's coral, 10s.; 1 shirt-stud, 1s.; 1 key, 1s.; 1 watch-ring, 1s.; and 1 seal, 10s.; her property: 2nd COUNT, for burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house:—also for stealing, on the 15th of April, at Putney, 40 sovereigns, 80 half-sovereigns, and 40 half-crowns, the monies of the said
Fanny Stewart, in her dwelling-house, to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(John Wilson, of No. 90, High-street, Southwark, deposed to his good character.)

1205.
WILLIAM WEBB was indicted
for feloniously forging, on the 26th of March, an acquittance and receipt for 19s. 10d. with intent to de
fraud
Joseph Rule: 2nd COUNT, for uttering the same with the like intent.
JOSEPH RULE . I am a grocer and cheesemonger, and live at No. 74, Suffolk-street, Southwark. On the 26th of March last, about half-past

eight o'clock in the morning, a woman came to my shop and asked for some tobacco—about two hours after she was gone, the prisoner came in—he asked me if I was a buyer of soap and candles—I said, "No"—I asked him to show me a list, which he produced—I asked if he was a traveller for that party, which was James Hibbald, whose name appeared on the list—I knew that house—the prisoner represented that he came from James Hibbald—he said so—he mentioned the name of James Hibbald, of No. 119, Bishopsgate-street—I gave him an order for a pound of rotten stone, and a pound of black lead, as a sample, to be supplied from James Hibbald's bouse—he brought the goods himself about three o'clock in the afternoon, with this paper marked A—the writing was all there with the exception of the receipt, which he wrote before me, "Settled same time, J. H."—I paid the money, 6s., and he wrote that as the receipt—he put the "J. H." in my presence—those goods were genuine—he left a sack, and said he would call again at seven o'clock in the after
noon—about an hour after he left, the same female who had been before came in again—the prisoner called again at seven o'clock—I asked him if he could bring me 141bs. of each, the same as the sample—he said he would—he brought 14lbs. of each—I did not undo those goods till I went to Worship-street—I then undid one parcel which he had represented as 14lbs. of black lead, and there was only 4lbs. of black lead, the rest was coal—that bill came to 19s. 10d.—I paid him, and he signed that bill before me the same as the other—he affected to have authority to sign Hibbald's name—I was surprised at his signing "J. H."—I asked him how it was he brought me a bill, not a printed bill head—he said he was so late that night, he merely wrote it out in a hurry—when he went away, I asked him to leave me one of those lists—he refused, saying he had only one—he said he would send me one with the goods—as fast as I bought these goods a woman came to buy them again—she said she would pay me directly, but I did not let her have them—I have never seen her since—I have the goods and the bills here—I went to Mr. Hibbald's next morning, on discovering rubbish instead of the things I had ordered—he represented himself as a seller of soap and candles, and produced this list, which I looked over—I asked the price of the black lead and rotten stone—I asked if I could have 1lb. of each as a sample—he said decidedly so.

Q. But in this particular transaction, he affected to come from Hibbald, to supply you with Hibbald's goods, and gave you a receipt as having autho
rity to do so from Hibbald? A. Yes, and by that means he got the 6s. of my money—this is the bill and receipt—(read)—"London, March 26th, 1845: Mr. Rule, bought of J. Hibbald, 1/4 ream of glass paper, at 15s. the ream, 3s. 9d.; 1lb. of stone blue, 10d.; lib. of lead, 10d.; lib. of rotten stone, 7d.; total, 6s."—that was the state in which he brought it, as a bill coming from Hibbald's, for goods with which he had supplied me in the name of Hibbald, and when I gave him the money he gave me this as Hibbald's receipt for what I had had, "Settled same time, J. H."

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you mean that was written in your presence? A. It was—not the whole of it, but "Settled same time, J. H."—the goods first supplied were genuine—the rotten stone had been damped, to weigh heavier—they were not worth the money I gave for them.

Q. Then how came you to take them? A. Well, I never did business in that way before, but having a customer coming and asking for these things, I told her I could get them for her—I saw the samples before I paid for them.

JAMES HIBBALD . I am an oilman, and live at No. 119, Bishopsgate-street. I do not know the prisoner—he was not my traveller, or in my employ—this bill was not written by my authority—my bills are printed—the heading is not exactly our form—we have the number, and name of the street—it is merely "London" here, and my bill heads are made out "James Hibbald," in full length—I sell such things as are men
tioned in this paper—neither the bill, nor what purports to be the acquit
tance, was written by any authority from me.

COURT to JOSEPH RULE. Q. Did your faith in the genuineness of this receipt lead to a further transaction by which you were a sufferer? A. It did, to the supply of unreal goods—I believed the receipt to be the genuine authority of Mr. Hibbald, whose initials it bore, to be the receipt of his servant, in discharge of a supposed debt contracted with him—be
lieving the genuineness of that receipt, I was led to deal with him thence-forth as the real servant of Mr. Hibbald—when I was an apprentice, I always signed a receipt "Settled same time," and my master's name, the same as this—I believed it was genuine—I gave faith to it as genuine, and acted on the footing of its being genuine.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner,)

(The Jury stated their belief that the name of Hibbald was assumed without his authority, for the purpose of fraud, and was the means of putting off goods to the prosecutor as those of Hibbald, when they were not so.)

1206.
WILLIAM WEBB was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 4th of April, a forged request for the delivery of 1 gallon of rum, and 1/2 a gallon of brandy, with intent to defraud
William Carter.
WILLIAM BAKER . I keep the Noah's Ark, Blackfriars-road. On the 4th of April the prisoner came to my house and produced a note, which I accidentally destroyed.
NOT GUILTY .

1207.
WILLIAM WEBB was again indicted
for feloniously and know
ingly uttering a forged request for the delivery of 1 gallon of gin, and 1/2 a gallon of brandy, with intent to defraud
William Knott.

WILLIAM KNOTT . I keep the Stamford Arms, in Stamford-street, Blackfriars-joad. On the 4th of April the prisoner came to my house and produced this paper—I knew Mr. Godfrey, of No. 86, Bankside—I deal with him—the prisoner said he was sent by Mr. Godfrey for a gallon of gin, and half a gallon of brandy—he had a leather apron on, such as Mr. Godfrey's men wear—I supposed him his servant, and I delivered to him a gallon of gin and half a gallon of brandy, which he took away—I have known the prisoner for a long time, which removed my suspicion.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You never saw him in Mr. God
frey's employment? A. I have seen him with Mr. Godfrey's carman—I do not know his name—I cannot say whether the prisoner said he came from Mr. Godfrey or Mr. Godfrey's.

NATHANIEL GODFREY . I am a vinegar-merchant, and live at No. 86, Bankside, Southwark. The prisoner was never in my service—this order is not my handwriting—I did not authorise any body to put my name to it, nor did I order the articles—the "Godfrey" is a very good imitation of my writing, but not the "N."
Cross-examined. Q. You have no knowledge of the prisoner? A. Not at all—a man named Thomas Turner was in my employ as carman—I
should be very glad to know where he is now—it is not like his writing—he left me on Easter Monday, long before this occurred.

THOMAS TURVEY (policeman.) I received charge of the prisoner at Mr. Hick's, in Pearl-row, on the 4th of April—I have the goods that were obtained from Mr. Knott—they were left at a house in Gravel-lane, three or four hundred yards from Mr. Knott's—I took the person who had them to the police-office, and they would not identify the prisoner as the man who had brought them there—this was the day they were obtained—they were afterwards sent to Mr. Godfrey—(the order was here read.)
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 41.—

1208.
WILLIAM WEBB was again indicted
for feloniously and know
ingly uttering, on the 4th of April, a forged request for the delivery of I gallon of gin, and I gallon of rum, with intent to defraud
James Hicks.

JAMES HICKS . I live in Pearl-row, Blackfriars-road, and am a licensed victualler. On the 4th of April, about twelve o'clock, the prisoner brought this paper to me—I opened and read it—I said, "Is this Mr. Godfrey's handwriting?"—he said, "Yes"—I told him it would take me some little time to execute the order—he asked me if I had got no bottle—I said yes I had plenty of bottles, but I liked to do business so that I might be led into no dilemma or error, and I should send for a permit—he said, "How long will it be before I shall call again?"—I said it might be an hour or more, as permit writers sometimes were busy, and could not attend—he said, "Then I will call again in about an hour and a half, or two hours, and bring Mr. Godfrey's cart with me"—as soon as he went I despatched an old gentleman, who I send on errands, down to Mr. Godfrey—I told him I had some suspicion before he went—he came back in about half an hour from Mr. Godfrey's, and Mr. Godfrey's servant with him—when the prisoner came again I said to him, "This is a forgery, Mr. God
frey did not write it, or his clerk; how came you by it?"—he said, "Mr. Godfrey's servant gave it to me"—I said, "You have got to prove that, to find Mr. Godfrey's servant"—I gave him in charge—Mr. Godfrey's servant said he knew nothing of him—I live about a mile from Bankside.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. This servant who came from Mr. Godfrey's was a livery servant, was he not? A. Yes, not a carman—the order was sealed up—I asked the prisoner if it was Mr. Godfrey's order, and he said, "Yes, I had it from Mr. Godfrey's man"—he brought no cart with him—I do not know Turner—he had no score at my house.
COURT. Q. Did the prisoner bring anything that he could carry the things away in? A. No—another of Mr. Godfrey's carmen came afterwards.
NATHANIEL GODFREY . This note is not my writing, nor written by my authority—Turner left me on the 24th of March—this is not Turner's handwriting I am certain—I never saw the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was Turner in your employ? A. Two years—the servant that went to Mr. Hicks is a brother of his—he is here—one of my clerks sent him to Mr. Hicks—Turner had an opportunity of seeing me write—he could write himself, but not at all in this style—I saw his writing constantly for two years—I do not know where he is—he is no relation of mine or my wife's—I have given directions to have him apprehended—I went to Mr. Traill three times—he said he would have him published in the Hue and Cry.
HENRY TURNER . I was not examined before the Magistrate, or at all in this case.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know where your brother is? A. No—I heard from him last about a fortnight after this took place—he was then down in Somersetshire—I did not tell my master or the officer—I did not know they were searching for him—I went with them once to search for him at a place where they thought he was lodging, but he was not there—I could not tell where he was to be found—that was before I had the letter.

COURT. Q. Under what circumstances did he leave Mr. Godfrey? A. He was too long gone with goods on Greenwich fair day—Mr. Godfrey complained of it, and they parted—I never saw the prisoner till the day he was taken—I have been with Mr. Godfrey above four years.

MR. HICKS re-examined. When the prisoner came to me he was dressed in a leather apron up to his collar, with a strap of leather round, much like the dress worn by Mr. Godfrey's men—I asked him both if it was Mr. Godfrey's order, and if it was Mr. Godfrey's handwriting.

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Two Years.

1209.
WILLIAM CHURCHILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of May, at Camberwell, 1 wooden till, value 2s. 6d.; and 3 pence; the property of
Airth Mungo, in his dwelling-house; and afterwards, about the hour of one in the night, burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am pot
man to Mr. Airth Mungo, who keeps the George public-house in the Camberwell-road, in the parish of Camberwell. I fastened up the house on Sunday night, the 4th of May, about twelve o'clock, or twenty minutes after—I fastened the front door with an iron bar and a prop, and the back door in the same way—there is an inner door near the bar, leading to the private part of the house, that fastens with I bolt only, nearest to the bar—I bolted it—about ten minutes after one I was called by the police—I went down stairs, and found the till taken out of its place, and put on the counter—I had left it in its place under the counter, and a little copper money in it—I believe none was taken—the doors were all three unfastened and open—about eleven o'clock on the Sunday night I had seen three persons in the tap-room—I believe the prisoner to be one of them—I saw them come in and out—the last time I saw them was coming in—I did not go into the tap-room after that, and did not see them go out—when called by the police I observed some soot on the counter, and likewise about the stove in the tap-room—I saw a cap and a pair of shoes lying there—they were also sooty—a person could get from the back of the house over the garden fence, and so get away over an open piece of ground—the policeman has the shoes.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You did not take anything into the tap-room to them? A. No, I did not—I was at the bar, and could see them—our house is a kind of passage; people walk through all the day long; they use it as a thoroughfare into George-street, which leads into Southampton-street and into New Peckham—it is out of the way to Camberwell-green—I know Wells by sight—he comes in sometimes, like another customer—he lives just behind the house.
MR. PAYNE. Q. Did Wells come in that morning after the police were there? A. Yes, at one o'clock—he told them something—the soot appeared as if somebody had been up the chimney.

CHARLOTTE MUNGO . I am the wife of Airth Mungo, who keeps the I George. I saw Smith close the house about twelve o'clock—I went into the tap-room, and put the gas out—it was then, as near as possible, twenty minutes or a quarter to twelve—there were no persons in the tap-room then, to my knowledge—I looked under the places—I did not look up the chimney—I observed no soot there—I saw it afterwards—there was not much—might have been so when I was there, and I not observe it—there was no cap or shoes lying on the floor, and the tills were in their proper places—when I came down, after being disturbed, I found one of the tills on the counter, and a pair of shoes, a cap, and some soot in the tap-room.

WILLIAM HENRY CUNNINGHAM . I am a water-man or kind of ostler at the George. I was in the tap-room on Sunday night, the 4th of May, and saw the prisoner and two others there—they first came into the tap-room about half-past nine o'clock—I left at twenty minutes before eleven—the prisoner and the other two men were then there, by themselves.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure of that? A. Quite certain—they had one pot of beer—one of them brought it into the tap-room—nobody in particular waits on the customers—I do sometimes when I am there—I did not take any beer in to them—I was sitting against the door, and they were by the fire—I sat facing them—they sat there all the time—the man brought the beer in when he came in at first—they did not go out afterwards in my presence—they talked very little—the man with the beer came in behind the others—he was a tall man—I do not know hit name—I had seen him before—he was there three Sunday evenings before that—he was a dark-complexioned young man—I was at the police-office—I saw some of the prisoner's witnesses there—neither of them were the tall man that came in—I did not speak to the prisoner or either of the others—I was sleepy.
MR. PATNE. Q. Were there other persons in the tap-room besides those three men? A. No, nobody else, all the time, and I left them there.

ALEXANDER HOPPER (police-constable P 183.) On Monday rooming, the 5th of May, at one o'clock, I was on duty in Camber well-road—I tried the door of the George public-house, and thought it rather gave in—I pressed against it again, and hallooed out to my brother constable that I did not consider it was all right—I heard a noise inside like a dog, or something shoved against the door—a bar, which was laid against it, fell, and I got in—I observed the till on the counter, with some coppers in it—the back door was unsecured, the bolts out—anybody could hare got out there while I was coming in at the front—I found a pair of shoes, one on the stove, and the other lying below, with soot, and a cap with soot on it—I found nobody there—Wells came in about twenty-five minutes after I had first gone in, and three policemen—from what Wells said to me I went in search of the prisoner, and about eleven o'clock on Monday evening I found him in the stable-loft in Waterloo-street, Camberwell, apparently asleep—I shook him, and asked if he slept there last night—he said yes, he did—a gentleman there said, "Bill, you know you did not"—he then said he did not—I asked him where he had been on the Sunday night—he said he had been at the Boyton Arms (which is a beer-shop on the banks of the canal) with two others; that the landlord closed up the house, (he did not mention the time;) from there he came down Southampton-street, and went to the Elephant and Castle, and had some coffee at a coffee-stall kept

by a female; that he emained there a consideranle time, and went from there to a public-house—as we were taking him away he said, "I know what it is for; it is about the George"—my brother constable brought him to the station—I took off the shoes which he had on, and put on the pair which I found in the prosecutor's house—he put one of them on—he turned them over, and said, "They are not my shoes," but the left shoe exactly fitted him—he only tried on one—I found marks in the graden adjoining the back of the prosecrtor's house, going from the back into George-street—I could not say whether they were the foot-marks of a person with or without shoes, the ground was so very hard.

Cross-examined. Q. It is a gravel-road, is it not? A. Yes—the footmarks were not on the road, but in the adjoining gardens—they came along the ditch—I cannot say how many persons' footmarks there were—Idid not go to the Elephant and Castle to look for a woman there—there is a woman sells coffee there.

NICHOLAS BUTLER (police-constanle P 314.) On Sunday night, or Mon
day morning, I was on duty in Camberwell-road at a quarter after one o'clock, and about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's house, I met the prisoner and two others coming in a direction from the prosecutor's house towards London—I observed that the prisoner had no shoes on, and no cap or hat—I took particular notice of him—I carry a light with me and used it—which means beat a constable or somebody—I folowed them about ten yards—they were walking three abreast, very fast—the prisoner and the one nearest to me were somking pipes—I have no doudt about the prosoner—I described him to my fellow-constable in the morning.

Cross-examined. Q. They walked pretty freely? A. They walked very fast, right by me—the prisoner spoke loud—Ihave heard the word malleting used before in the West of England, and in London as well, and different places, before I was in the police—I was them a bricklayer—it is used among bricklayers as well as others, and means the same thing—I had no grounds for stopping them then.

GEORGE ROUS (police-constable P 219.) On the mirning of the 5th of may, about ten road, half-way between Camberwell-gate and the George—I was turinng to go into the square, about mid-way form Southampton-street to where my brother constable was, which was neared the gate, and saw three man pass me in a direction for Londom—I saw one of them without shoes—I did not see his face—I observed his feet when he had passed—I looked after him sufficient to see he was without shoes—I observed his height and genertal appearance, and have no doudt the prisoner is the man—I did not observe his head—he was outside the other two, and about half a step before them.

Cross-examined. Q. Was anybody with you? A. No—I did not observe that he was talking—I never rememner having seen him before—I did not observe whether he had a hat or cap on—I could hear him slouching as if without shoes—that induced me to turn my attention to him—he made a different noise to what he would if he had shoes—I could hear the noise—Butler was nearer to London than I was.

JAMES KEARNE (police-constable P 36.) I assisted in taking the prisoner into custdy—he appeared to be asleep—I awoke him up—when he saw me he said, "I know what you want me for, it is the George affair"—
in coming along I asked him again whether he knew anything respecting the George—he said, "I will not answer that question."

Cross-examined. Q. Was your question to him, "Were you there?" A. It was, and he said, "I shall answer no questions"—it was in the loft when I aroused him, that he said, "I know what you want me for, it is the George affair," but it was in coming along I said, "Were you there?"—he did not say he was not there—I never heard him say so—this is my writing—(the deposition being read stated, "I said, 'Were you there?' he denied it; I afterwards asked him, and he said, 'I shall answer no ques
tions' ")—he never did deny it—he said, "I shall answer you no questions"—he did say he was not there—hearing that read over has altered my recollection a little.

JAMES WELLS . I am a labourer, and live at No. 3, George-street, Camberwell-road, at the back of the George public-house. On Monday morning, the 5th of May, or the middle of Sunday night, I was awoke by the springing of a rattle—I got up and went out to see what was the matter—the policeman said, would I spring his rattle—I went and sprang it for other policemen to come—I then returned back to the George, and saw a pair of shoes on the bar—these aie them—I knew them to be the prisoners directly—I have known him about five months, to the best of my recollection—he slept in the loft of Mr. Bullock's stable, in Waterloo-street—about a quarter to five o'clock that same morning I went to that stable—he was not there—he was to come to work with me—he did not come during that day—I did not see him until five o'clock that evening, at the Waterloo Arms—he had an old pair of shoes on then—I said, "Bill, where are your prads" meaning shoes—he made no answer—I know the shoes produced—they are the shoes the prisoner gave to the shoemaker, or whatever he calls himself, to have an under
lay put on the right shoe, and the upper-leather of the left was to be sewn up—I was present when he gave them to the shoemaker in the public-house on the Saturday week before the robbery—I saw before the Magistrate the shoes the prisoner had on then—they were not the shoes I had seen him give to the shoe-maker—I have seen him wearing these shoes every day—I am quite certain they are his shoes.

Cross-examined. Q. You swear these are the shoes that were given to the shoemaker in the public-house? A. Yes—I never got into any scrape but once, and that was nine years ago, about a few potatoes which I got from Mr. Tibbald's ground, a farmer at Peckham—I had to pay a fine for it—malleting means fighting—I live in a very respectable house—the landlady is a widow—I do not know her name—I keep the house—I am married—I was in bed when I heard the rattle spring—I went to the stable where the prisoner sleeps about a quarter to five to call him to come to work—that was my object, nothing else—there was no arrange
ment between us—I had then given information to the police that these shoes belonged to the prisoner—I did not tell the police then that I would show them where the prisoner was—I did about a quarter or twenty minutes before five—I told Hopper so—he and I went there together, and he was not there—I went with Hopper to have him apprehended if he had been there.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Was he to have worked with you that day? A. Yes, Mr. Rofy, my master, told me so—I made sure he would be at the stable at that time—the prisoner had worked for Mr. Rofy before, and was to do so that Monday.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Just point out what was done to shoes?—(handing him those found on the prisoner.) A. These are not the shoes—these are the shoes that were mended (looking at the others)—the pri
soner told the shoemaker to put a piece under the right shoe, and the left was to be soled and heeled—I heard all that was directed to be done, at the Waterloo Arms, on the Saturday week before this Sunday—I do not know the shoemaker's name, I know the man—I saw him at the police-office—it was George Powell—I am not a shoemaker.

GEORGE POWELL . I am sometimes a navigator, and sometimes make shoes. On Saturday, the 26th of April, I received a pair of shoes from I the prisoner to mend, at the Waterloo Arms—I have practised shoemaking I occasionally for the last ten years—these are not the shoes—(looking at those found in the prosecutor's house)—I should say they would very nearly fit the prisoner—I know they are not his—these are the shoes I repaired for him—they are the shoes I received at the public-house, when Wells was present—(those taken from the prisoner's feet)—I know them by the work, and by the pair of plain tips that I put on them with five holes in them, and the back lining of each shoe was sewn with a needle and thread, by my wife—I received no other shoes but these at the Waterloo Arms—they are different to the others—I had them on the Saturday, and I took them to the prisoner's on the Sunday morning, about half-past eleven o'clock—these other shoes I never saw before I was at the police-office—they are a similar cut shoe to the prisoner's—those I mended are Oxonians—I should not say the others would fit the prisoner—I never saw any of his shoes like these—he had on an old pair of blucher boots when I had these—he had no others to my knowledge—I hare known him quite well, and seen him frequently—this cap is not his—I never saw him wear a cap like it—he generally wears a blue cloth cap with a peak to it—(looking at one produced by the prisoner)—this is the cap he has generally worn—I never knew of his having one like the other.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How old are you? A. Twenty-five—I have known the prisoner pretty well all my life—I have mended shoes for him a great many times—I never mended a pair of oxonians for him before these—I will not swear the other shoes will not fit him—I should not say they would lit him as the others do—I never saw them tried on—I live at No. 6, Byatt's-buildings, George-street, Camberwell, not far from the George—it was between five and six o'clock on the Saturday that the prisoner gave me the shoes to mend—a fellow-servant, named Field, who works with the water-casks, was there, and Wells—I took them home to my own house about six o'clock—I mended them on Sunday morning from nine o'clock till about half-past eleven, when I took them home—there have been times when I have not seen the prisoner, when I have been at work, at no other time—I swear that—three months, I believe, is the longest time I have lost sight of him—he lived in Cork-street—for the last six months he has slept in a stable—I did not see him there, visit him at his house, or work with him, but I have worked for him—I have been to his father-in-law's, in Cork-street, where he did live—he has not lived there for the last six months—I have seen him at the Waterloo Arms, where he mostly had his meals.
SARAH POWELL . I am the wife of last witness. I assisted him in

mending a pair of shoes of the prisoner's on Sunday morning, the 27th of April—these are them—I sewed the back seam with black thread, and sewed the binding on—I know my work—these other shoes I have never seen—they have never been in our house, to my knowledge—my husband has been in the habit of mending for the prisoner for a considerable time-only myself and my husband were in the house at the time the shoes were mended.

MR. PAYNE. Q. You were not before the Magistrate, I believe? A. I was not—my husband had these shoes on the Saturday, and returned them on the Sunday—that was the only occasion on which I mended any shoes for the prisoner—I took no particular notice of them at the time—I have been married twelve months—I knew the prisoner before I was married.

MR. PRENDEROAST. Q. Do you perfectly well know the time you mended them? A. On the Sunday morning, the 27th of April—I am sure that was the day—I have seen the prisoner wearing a cap, but never one of this colour or description—there is another witness here who saw the shoes.

JOSEPH COOK . I saw the prisoner with a pair of shoes on Dun'aay, the 4th of May, the same Sunday this happened—it was a pair of ox
onians—the left one was torn towards the toe in front—this is it—these are the shoes—they had tips—I saw them after they were mended, before he had them on—the last witness is my sister.

MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. A shoemaker—I was not before the Magistrate—I was first applied to to speak about this matter the week before last, by Mr. Powell—I saw the prisoner on this Sunday standing outside Mr. Bolter's, the Waterloo Arms—he put up his feet to show Powell that he wanted his shoes mended—Powell said if he would let him have them on Monday he would do them—this was about half-past four o'clock in the afternoon—I had called to see my sister and brother-in-law, and we went out for a walk in the afternoon, and there saw the pri
soner—I have known him about six months—I knew he had had a pair mended the week before—I was at Powell's, and saw them before and after they were mended—they were only tipped and heeled, and he had worn the soles out and cut the front against a stone—they were the same shoes—I live in Boss-street, James-street, Horsleydown—I work on my own account—I used to work for a shop in the City—I have not had much work lately—I am very seldom with the prisoner—I law him with these shoes on twice—Powell had shown me what he had to do to the shoes, and when I saw the prisoner with them on, after they had been mended he showed me what had been done to them, and said he had made a good job of them.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you ever see him wear a cap at all like that? A. No—he wore a blue cap.

NEWHALL. I am the prisoner's father-in-law. I know his cap—this is not it—he never wore such a thing—he generally wore a blue cap with a peak to it, like this—my attention has not been directed to his shoes—I have looked after a coffee woman at the Elephant and Cattle, but have not been able to find her.

MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. A bricklayer—the prisoner has not lived with me for some months past—as I had two daughters grown up he said he would go out and get lodgings—I believe he slept in a bed in
the stable—I saw him most every day—I was before the Magistrate, and gave my account to him, but was not sworn.

JOHN DAVIS . I keep the Boyton Arms beer-shop, near the canal in New Church-road, Camberwell. The church bell-ringers practise the art of bell-ringing—we have a peal of seventeen bells for their practice—it is a society held in our club-room—I saw the prisoner at my house—I cannot say what time he came there—I saw him at half-past eleven o'clock, when he came down stairs to go away, and I saw him some short time before, between ten and o'clock I should think, sitting down with two others—he made a remark to me, which is the reason why I know him—he was in (be club-room where the bells were—it is open on Sunday evenings—I wu before the Magistrate—inspector Giffbrd sent the officers to know whether what the prisoner had stated as to being in my house was correct, and at I identified him they did not swear me.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of frequenting your beer-shop? A. No—I never saw him there but once before—there were very likely twenty or thirty persons in the room that night—I am not aware that there is anybody else here from my house—I did not see the prisoner after half-past eleven o'clock—I should say it was rather more than that—my house is about half a mile from the George, I suppose, but I never saw the house to my knowledge.

----LESTER. I am a bricklayer. I was at the Boyton Arms on the Sunday night of the robbery—I saw the prisoner there at half-past eight o'clock—he remained there till half-past eleven—I then left—I left the prisoner outside the door along with two more.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you often go to the Boyton Arms? A. I do generally on a Sunday—I am one of the bell-ringers—I only saw the pri
soner there once, and that was that night—I knew him before—I know this was on Sunday night, the 4th of May, a fortnight last Sunday—he asked me to drink twice—I did not see him after half-past eleven o'clock—I was not examined before the Magistrate.

JAMES HISTEY . I was examined before the Magistrate last Tuesday fortnight—I was at the Boyton Arms with the prisoner on the Sunday night when this burglary is said to have been committed—(I heard of bit being taken up on the Tuesday)—he remained there from eight o'clock till half-past eleven—I was with him all that time—we then went to the Anchor and Hope, and from there to the Elephant and Castle, to get some coffee—we got some—I was with the prisoner till half-past two on the Monday morning—I never saw him wear iuch a cap as this—he wore a blue cap—this is not my cap—I do not know whose it is—I never saw the house to my knowledge.

MR. PAYNE. Q. He did not generally wear such a cap? A. No, he never wore such a cap since I knew him—I had a bed to go to, and so had he—I cannot say why I did not go home—he gave me no reason for not going home—I left him at half-past two at the Elephant and Castle with Barton—they were drinking coffee—we were not doing anything besides drinking coffee—only standing against the Elephant and Castle—we did not get there till a few minutes before one—we had been drinking at the Boyton Arms from eight till half-past eleven—we had ale and beer—we then went to Mr. Reed's, the Anchor and Hope, in Southampton-street—that is not a great way from the George—the bottom of George-street opens into Southampton-street—we were not more than five or ten minutes

getting there—we staid at the Anchor and Hope about four or five minutes—we had half-a-pint of gin and cloves there—we went from there to the Elephant and Castle—I took no notice of the time, but the clock struck one very shortly after we had been standing there, because Barton pulled out his watch, and showed us—I had no pipe—I swear that.

Q. On your oath, did not you go into the George between the'time you left the Anchor and Hope, and your going to the Elephant and Castle? A. No, I swear I did not go near the George—we were doing nothing between leaving the Anchor and Hope, and going to the Elephant and Castle—we walked right along the road—I cannot say how long it took us, but I can swear we never went in anywhere after we left the Anchor and Hope—we went from the Duke of Clarence at the corner of Southampton-street right away up to the Elephant and Castle, straight up the Wai worth-road—the prisoner had snoes on—that I swear—Barton had on a white jacket, a pair of moleskin trowsers, and a cap—I will not be certain whether I had a pipe—I do not think I had—I believe the prisoner had a pipe—he had a cap on—I swear that—and his shoes also—I heard nothing said about malleting anybody—we saw a policeman against the Duke of Clarence—I said nothing to him, but Barton did—I do not know what he said—I cannot swear which policeman it was—I did not see another policeman near Addington-square as we were going along.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Had you got any young ladies that night t A, Not in our company—there was one came in with another party.

----BARTON. I am a bricklayer's labourer. I was at the Boyton Arms on this night—I had some money—the others had a little—I had had a pretty middling week—we went to hear the bell-ringing—we got there about eight o'clock, and stopped till about half-past eleven or a quarter to twelve—the prisoner was in my company all the time—neither of us went into the George between eight and half-past eleven—I am quite certain of that—after leaving the Boyton Arms we went to the Anchor and Hope, and then to the Elephant and Castle, where we had some coffee of a woman—about half-past two o'clock in the morning Histed went away—I and the prisoner stopped at the Elephant and Castle and had some more coffee—I remained in his company till seven o'clock next morning—during the whole of that time he was not in the George at all—I parted with him at Mr. Rofy's, where he works, opposite the Waterloo Arms, Camberwell—we went through the George to get there—it is a thoroughfare—I have known the prisoner as long as I have known myself—I know he had his shoes on while he was in my company—I do not know what particular shoes he had on—this cap is not his—I never saw him with a cap at all like it—I never saw it before that I am aware of—I went before the Magistrate to give evidence about the prisoner's being with me—I was sworn.

MR. PAYNE. Q. You left the Boyton Arms about half-past eleven? A. Yes, or a quarter to twelve—I will not be sure to a quarter of an hour—we were only a few minutes at the Anchor and Hope, just to stop and drink a glass of gin and cloves—I suppose we got to the Elephant and Castle a little before one—I heard the clock strike while I was there—it took us all that time to walk from the Anchor and Hope—we staid at the Elephant and Castle till half-past two, drinking coffee and eating bread and butter, and longer than that—I cannot say how much we had, or how much I paid—we were not trying people's doors—after drinking the coffee we went and had some more beer at a public-house just opposite St.

George's Church, on the same side of the way—we got there a little before four, as soon as it was open—we stopped at the coffee-stall from one till near four, drinking coffee and eating bread and butter—the prisoner sometimes works at Mr. Rofy's—he ought to have been at work there that Monday—he did not go home all night—he was along with me—we were drinking beer at the public-house till about half-past five, and then came back again to Camberwell—we got back at seven—no one was in our com
pany at the public-house—I believe I was smoking a pipe as we came along the Camberwell-road to the Elephant and Castle—I cannot tell whether the prisoner was smoking or not—we met a policeman—he did not turn his light on to look at us—that I swear—we met him at the corner of Southampton-street, near the Duke of Clarence—we did not meet one near the gate.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you speak to the policeman? A. Yes—it was Hopper—I changed half-a-sovereign at the Waterloo Arms in the evening—I had 2s. or 3s. left in the morning.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you alone, or was anybody with you when you saw and spoke to that policeman? A. The other two went on—I did not ask the policeman if he had seen a young man pass, dressed like a brick-layer, whom I called Bill—I met this policeman on the Saturday night, and asked him that question, but not on the Sunday night—I spoke to him, but what I said I do not know—it was at the corner just against the Duke of Clarence, about five or ten minutes past twelve.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you ever see the prisoner in such a cap as that? A. Never, and these shoes are not his—I never observed him with any like them.

COURT. Q. Where did he go to his work at seven o'clock in the morning? A. To Mr. Rofy's, in George-street—he worked there regularly in the watering time—I know Wells—I do not know whether it was at the same place where Wells was to go to work.

MR. PAYNE. Q. You do not mean to say that he did work at Mr. Rofy's that day? A. No, he did not—he went with the intent to do so—I saw him afterwards on the Monday—I did no work that day—we spent the greater part of the day at the Waterloo Arms.

----REED. I am landlord of the Anchor and Hope. I have no knowledge of the prisoner, but the last witness was at my house, with two other young men and two females, from twelve o'clock to perhaps ten minutes before twelve—I will not say exactly the time—they had half a pint of gin and cloves, for which Barton paid—they looked clean, particu
larly Barton—he looked very clean—neither of them looked as if they had come out of a chimney—I think they had caps on, and they were smoking—Barton lighted his pipe at my gas before he went out.

----BOLTER. I keep the Waterloo Arms, in George-street. The stable where the prisoner slept belongs to Mr. Bullock—a young man and he slept together in a loft over the stable—I saw the prisoner on the Monday morning, about seven o'clock—he had a cap on, and I think I should have observed if he had been without shoes—he did not look as if he had just come out of a chimney—he was dressed as usual—he was in the habit of assisting my man to clean my pots, and I reprimanded him well for not being there to do so—Mr. Rofy is a corn
chandler, opposite, and contracts for watering the roads—I never saw the prisoner in such a cap as this—he usually wore a blue cap.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Where does he live? A. I cannot say—he jobs about for most people in the neighbourhood, and sleeps at Mr. Bullock's loft—I was never up there—it is at the side of my house—they have a bed—I do not know the name of the young man that sleeps with him—it was. neither of the witnesses.

----NEWHALL re-examined. I have got the shirt here that the prisoner took off that morning—it is very dirty, but not the least stain of soot upon it—he came and changed it at my house on the Monday morning—I have kept it ever since without washing it, as they said he was found in the chimney.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you know this loft over the stable? A. Yes—I have been at work there—they had a rug and things to sleep upon—the man that looks after Mr. Bullock's horses and the prisoner slept there together.

NICHOLAS BUTLER . I would not swear that Histey and Burton were the two men who were with the prisoner, but I believe Burton, from his appearance, to be one of the men—I turned my light on his face—he after
wards owned to me that he did pass me, and that he touched me on the right elbow as he passed me.
GEORGE ROUS . I do not recollect either Histey or Burton.
NOT GUILTY .

1210.
GEORGE SHARP was indicted
for stealing 67 yards of calico, value 1l. 5s., the goods of
James Worley.

JAMES WORLEY . I am a woollen-draper, and live in Surrey-place, Newington Butts. About nine o'clock, on Saturday morning, the 3rd of May, I saw the prisoner come into my shop, take a piece of calico, put it under his arm, and walk off with it—I followed him, and called," Stop thief!"—I saw him drop it, and picked it up—it is my property.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you see it taken? A. I did—I was at the desk, in the middle of the shop—I could see the prisoner, but he could not see me—I am quite sure the person who took it was the person who threw it down.

GUILTY .** Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1211.
HENRY SWAN was indicted
for embezzling 10s., the property of
George Wren Le Grand, his master, and that he had been before con
victed of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1212.
CHARLES RENDALL was indicted for
stealing 971bs. of hay, value 4s., the property of
Henry Perkins, his master; and
WILLIAM WOODLAND
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the statute, &c.

JOHN COOPER . I am bailiff to Mr. Henry Perkins, of Hanworth-park, near Hounslow—on the 30th of April Rendall came there with some oats from Messrs. Barclay and Perkins's brewery—he is their drayman—the oats were all right—I took them in and they were put into the granary—there

could not have been two trusses of hay in the wagon then without my seeing them—Mr. Perkin's hay was kept in the loft in the farm-yard—I saw two trusses of hay afterwards at Wandsworth, which looked very much like that my master had in the loft—I did not give any hay to Rendall—no one was authorised to do so.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What time did Rendall come with the oats? A. About eleven o'clock—I was a little way from home—he told me he had waited about half an hour, he could not unload till I came home—Mr. Perkin's farm is about 400 acres, and has sometimes a good many persons about.

THOMAS THOMPSON . I am a labourer in the service of Mr. Perkins—on the 30th of April I saw Rendall in the farm-yard, between one and two o'clock—I saw him take a truss of hay up from the ground and put it in his wagon—there was no other hay in the wagon at that time—I then went to dinner and when I came out I noticed the wagon again—there was then two trusses of hay in it—his wagon was not above eight or ten yards from the hay-loft—I saw the hay which was afterwards brought from Wands-worth, and it was very similar to what Mr. Perkins had—I made the rick myself and had used a great deal of it.

JOHN FIELDER .
