I am a labourer and live in Gray's-inn-place, Holborn—I was a stranger to Rendall, but I overtook him driving a wagon near the Old Ship at Richmond on the 30th of April—he gave me a ride in his wagon, and after I had been in a few minutes he asked me to drive the horses and hold the reins—he went to sleep on the wagon—I moved the tarpaulin and saw some hay under it—I went on to the Plough at Wands-worth—we got out there to have a pot of beer—we got there about four o'clock, and remained about a quarter of an hour—when I came out of the house I saw Rendall talking to Woodland who is the under ostler there—they were standing under a shelter outside the house where persons sit down—I went to the wagon again and found the tarpaulin was lying down flat, and what it had covered was gone—I went into the tap-room again and soon after Daley, the officer, came in—Rendall was sitting alongside of me—the officer asked for Barclay and Perkins's drayman—Rendall said nothing, but the landlord came in and pointed him out—the officer asked Rendall if he had any hay on his wagon—he said he had none—the officer said he must go out and see about it.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You were sitting in the wagon driving? A. Yes, when I got up into the wagon Rendall went to sleep—I saw some hay when I happened to lift the tarpaulin—I remained io my seat—I could see into the road from the tap-room.

HENRY ORGER . I am a tallow-chandler and live at Putney. On the 30th of April, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was going towards the Plough public-house, at Wandsworth—I saw Barclay and Perkins's wagon standing before the Plough—I saw Woodland remove the tarpaulin and take from the wagon something bulky, which appeared to be hay—he took it into the stable—I walked on till I was opposite the wagon—I saw him return and take a second truss of hay from the wagon—he placed them one on the other in the first stall in the stable, and he locked the stable door—the horses were not in the stable, they were in the wagon—I took the number of the wagon, and I met Daley, the officer—I then accompanied him to the Plough and pointed out Woodland as the person who had removed the hay—Daley asked him where the hay was that he had taken

from the wagon—he made a deal of shuffling—he first said he knew nothing about it, and afterwards he said he would tell the truth, there was the hay, and he brought it out—on the way to the station he said, "I will tell the truth, I took the hay from the wagon by order of the wagoner"—Daley told him to hold his tongue, he wanted to hear nothing from him, and what he said he should be obliged to repeat in evidence—Daley brought Rendall out of the public-house and asked him what he had done with the hay that was on his wagon—he said, "Hay, what hay? I know nothing about any hay"—Daley told him he could prove he had hay—he said he had no hay—Daley told him if he denied it he must arrest him, and he must cottager himself in custody—the two prisoners were taken to the station.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. What are you? A. A tallow-chandler—I live in Gardener's-lane, Putney. I am in the employ of Willshire and Son, of Crucifix-lane, Bermondsey—the greater part of my time I am out getting orders and collecting money—I work in the factory, and am partly a town traveller—I have been there since the latter end of Nov.—I have collected outstanding debts for respectable gentlemen, and when they have been sued for, I have served the process.

THOMAS DALEY (police-constable V 127.) I received information from Orger—I went to the Plough—I saw the wagon, with "Barclay and Perkins" on it—I first spoke to Woodland—I asked him what he had done with the hay which he took off the wagon—he made no answer—I asked him a second time—he said nothing, but went to go to the public-house—I stopped him, and said, "I want that hay you took out of the wagon, and put into the stable"—he opened the stable door, and gave it me outr—I then went into the tap-room, and saw Rendall—I asked for Barclay and Perkins's man—Rendall made no answer, but the landlord pointed him out—I then asked what he had done with'the hay he had on the wagon—he said, "I had none on"—I said, "Come out and see"—I brought him to the wagon, and said, "Do you mean positively to say you had no bay on this wagon?"—he said, "I do"—when we were going away I said, "Don't say anything to each other, for if you do, I am bound to produce it in evidence"—Woodland then said, "Old man, I want a word with you; you ought not to have taken all the hay, it looks so much"—I then cautioned him again, and he said, "I will tell the troth; I did take it off the wagon, but it was by order of the wagon, pointing to Rendall, who was in custody of the other officer.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How many persons were in the tap-room? A. I think about four—I believe they were drinking and talking—Fielder and Rendall sat together.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Do you know how long Woodland has been ostler there? A. He has been under-ostler, I think, for nine or ten years—I have been on duty in that vicinity for fifteen years—I never heard anything against him.

DAVID FERNIE . I am a haybinder, in Mr. Perkins's service—I have seen the two trusses of hay which were found at the Plough—they were my binding, and Mr. Perkins's property—these are the bands—they are my making—I do not work for anybody else—I can tell my own binding from any other.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Are these anything more than hay twisted round and round into the shape of a roller? A. No.
JURY. Q. Do you ever leave the bands, that they may be taken away before you put them on the trusses? A. I never leave any, except they are on the trusses.

JOHN COOPER
re-examined. The hay was under my charge—the loft was never kept locked—I have not missed any hay.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

WOODLAND—
GUILTY . Aged 57.

RENDALL—
GUILTV . Aged 27.

1213.
JANE TURNER was indicted
for stealing 1 table-cover, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
John Askew.

JOHN ASKEW . I carry on business at No. 110, Blackman-street, Bo
rough. On the evening of the 18th of April I was standing on the stain, and saw the prisoner sitting by the side of my counter—she took a table-cover from the counter, folded it, and put it under her shawl—I came down and waited about two minutes—she was sitting by the side of the counter—I told my man to go for the policeman—she then took the cover from under her shawl, and said, "What, about this"—she said she was going to ask the price of it—she had not bought anything then.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. The person who was with her did buy something? A. Yes, and it was higher in price than this table-cover, it was a hearth-rug, which came to about 5s. or 6s.—I cannot say what the prisoner's intention might be—she brought the cover out at once, as soon as I talked about the policeman—I believe her friends are very respectable—I believe it was her sister who was with her—the prisoner is not married, her sister is—I said, "These people don't want to buy a hearth-rug," and they had not bought one then, but after I sent for the policeman they bought one and paid for it—I think I have stated all that happened—I think the prisoner might be tempted to take this cover, from being placed in favourable circumstances for so doing, as the young men were out of the way, except the person who was serving the rug—after I had told the young man to go for the policeman, the prisoner said she wanted to ask the price of the cover—I told her, and she said it was too much—I was willing to sell it, but she would not pay the price.

COURT. Q. Do you mean that after you charged her with stealing it; she asked the price? A. Yes, and I said, "You don't want to buy one;" but she persisted in asking the price—I said it was 6s.—she said it was too much—it had cost me less than the rug did.
NOT GUILTY .

1214.
JOHN JONES was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 3l., the goods of
James Brooks; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ANN BROOKS . I am the wife of James Brooks; we live in Devonshire-street, Lambeth. On the 19th of Nov. the prisoner, whom I knew before, came and dined with me—I went out, and asked him to remain while I went out—I came back in about ten minutes, and he was gone—I heard something, and went into the back parlour—my husband's watch was gone, which had been safe when I went away—this is it.
EMILY SNELGROVE . I saw the prisoner come out of Mrs. Brooks's
house—he had the watch in his hand—I saw the chain, and knew it was Mr. Brooks's.
JOHN MELVILLE . This watch was pawned with me on the 20th of Nov., I believe by the prisoner.

JOHN WILLIAMSON (police-constable G 198.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Westminster—(read—Convicted 28th Jan., 1845, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1215.
CATHERINE GREEN was indicted
for stealing 1 gown, the goods of
Alice Barber.

ALICE BARBER . I am a widow, and live at Rotherhithe. I left my gown behind the door on the 5th of April, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, leaving the door locked—I returned on the Monday following—I found the door open, and the gown gone—the prisoner was not at home—I lodge there, and her husband belongs to the house—when she came home I asked her where my dark gown was—she said she took it and pawned it, and would get it me again.
Prisoner. She lent me the gown. Witness. I did not.
JOHN WADHAM . I am a pawnbroker. This gown was pawned on the 5th of April by the prisoner, in the name of Ann Davis, which is the name she goes by.
Prisoner. She is my husband's own aunt.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Three Months.

1216.
THOMAS REDDY was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Askew, about the hour of three in the night of the 17th of April, in St. George the Martyr, Southwark, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 2 coats, value 2l. 10s.; 1 half-sovereign, 3 shillings, 9 groats, 36 pence, and 24 halfpence; his property.

JOHN ASKEW . I am a draper, and live at No. 110, Blackman-street, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark. I left my coat hanging in the counting-house at ten o'clock on Thursday night, the 17th of April—there was a letter in the pocket—the coat and letter now produced are what I left there—I was not the last up that night, nor the first up the next morning—I looked at the skylight over the counting-house the next morning, and part of the frame of it was broken—they had first broken a square, and opened a small light, and then opened the skylight, and got in—I missed the coat which had the letter in it.

JOHN BROWN . I am shopman to the prosecutor. I saw the skylight safe on the night of the 17th of April at ten o'clock—I was the last person in the shop—I locked the shop, and all was safe—there was a half-sovereign, three shillings, nine groats, thirty-six pence, and twenty-four bal£ pence in the till—I awoke in the morning about six o'clock, and went down a few minutes after—I then found the skylight broken—they had entered the shop, and taken the money from the till, and I missed two coats from the counting-house—all the drawers in the counting-house had been broken open, and the papers were all about the floor.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were there many things stolen? A. Only the coats and money.

CHARLES CHAMBERS (City police-constable, No. 523.) I was on duty in Lime-street at half-past five o'clock on the morning of the 18th of April—I saw the prisoner in company with another man—I saw the pri
soner had a coat on which was too large for him—the other man ran away—I went and took the prisoner—I asked him where he got that coat—he said he bought it four or five months ago in Petticoat-lane—I took him to the station—the inspector found this letter in the pocket of the coat—this is the coat he had on.

STEPHEN MARTIN (police-constable M 98.) I saw the prisoner about ten minutes past one o'clock in the morning on the 18th of April—he passed me—he had not this coat on then, and was going towards the pro
secutor's house.

GUILTY .— Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1217.
GEORGE DEAN was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
George Gray, from his person.

GEORGE GRAY . I live in Holy well-street, Milbank. On the 20th of April, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in Battersea-fields—I saw a young man struck down by a horse—I approached the crowd, and I had not remained above a minute or two before I felt some
thing at my pocket—I turned, and saw a lad with my handkerchief in his hand—I endeavoured to recover it from him, but in doing so he dropped it and got away—I gave an alarm—I am sure it was my handkerchief—I could not swear it was the prisoner who dropped it—I had only a glance at his face—I believe he is the person—he was exactly like him in size and clothing.

WILLIAM BROWN . I live in Bridge-road, Battersea, and am a carpenter. I was in the crowd, and saw the prisoner draw a handkerchief between me and Mr. Gray—I am sure it was the prisoner—he stood behind me and Mr. Gray—I saw his hand draw from between me and Mr. Gray—the prisoner turned round, and Mr. Gray turned and laid hold of him by the cuff of his coat—I saw the handkerchief drop from the prisoner—I am sure it dropped from him, and he ran away.
Prisoner. Q. Where were you standing? A. By the side of Mr. Gray.
Prisoner. You know it is false, I was lying down on the grass; this man came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

1218.
WILLIAM THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing 1 barrow, value 1l. 10s.; 1 board, 4s. 6d.; 2 pewter pots, 1s. 5d.; and 15 quarts of gooseberries, 9s.; the goods of
George James Honor Goff, his master.

GEORGE JAMES HONOR GOFF . I live in Regent-street, Lambeth. On the 8th of June, 1843, the prisoner came and asked me for a job—I hired him, and on the 10th of June I gave him a barrow, a board, and fifteen gallons of gooseberries to sell—he was to bring me home the money or the goods—he did not come back—I saw no more of him nor the goods till I lately found him in Lambeth workhouse—he said when I first asked him that he knew nothing about it, and then he said he went to a house at New-cross to get some refreshment, that somebody had taken the barrow away, and he was ashamed to return.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1219.
JAMES WOOD was indicted
for stealing 3lbs. 10ozs. weight of flour, value 8d.; and 7lbs. weight of bread, 10d.; the goods of
Henry King, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Two Months.

1220.
THOMAS LILLYWALL was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Joseph Hunt, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH HUNT . I am a waiter, and live in Union-street, Southwark. On the 1st of May, a few minutes before twelve o'clock, I was in the Bel
videre-road at the entrance of the Suspension-bridge—I felt a tug at my pocket—I turned, and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—I seized him by the collar, and told him to drop it—he dropped the handkerchief, and Evans took it up—it is mine—this is it—I gave him to the officer.

THOMAS EVANS . I live in Robert-street, Bedford-row. I was standing close to the prosecutor—I saw the prisoner drop the handkerchief from his hand behind him—I took it up—the prosecutor called out." That is mine"—the handkerchief is here now.

JEREMIAH LYNCH (police-constable M 188.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Onslow's office—(read—Convicted 4th of July, 1843, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY .** Aged 27.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1221.
ELIZABETH WATSON was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 3s.; 3 sovereigns, and 5 shillings; the monies of
John Taylor, from his person.

JOHN TAYLOR . I live in Salisbury-crescent, Walworth. On the 30th of April, about ten or eleven o'clock at night, I was in the Dover-road, on my way home—the prisoner addressed me, and asked me to give her a glass of ale—in order to get rid of her I consented, as I had been annoyed on similar occasions—she wished me to go to a public-house which I did not like the appearance of—I said I would give it her at another house—we crossed the road for that purpose, and she was leading me a way I did not like, and wished to get away—I turned and saw two men who were following us, the prisoner being close to me, and speaking vociferously tome—one of the men then passed very close, and thrust the prisoner against me—the men then went off, one one way, and the other the other—immediately after I said, "I must go," and the prisoner let go of my arm—I put my hand to feel for my purse and watch, and I missed my purse which contained three sovereigns and some silver, which I had seen safe about two hours before.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was there not something tender going on? A. No—her cheek was close to mine—I kept her about ten mi
nutes, and then gave her into custody—I believe there was only 2 1/2d. found on the prisoner—I was sober—lam not married—I was walking with the prisoner for ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—she had hold of me.
WILLIAM DAVIS (police-constable M 125). I took the prisoner—there was nothing found on her but 2 1/2d.
NOT GUILTY .

1222.
WILLIAM LEWIN was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged receipt for money, with intent to defraud
John Oakley.

JOHN OAKLEY . I am a black-lead manufacturer. The prisoner was in my employ as a packer—on the 11th of March I sent him to Mr. March, for some labels—he was to pay for them—I gave him a sovereign and j written order to get them—on the following morning he produced the labels with this bill and receipt, with Mr. March's name to it—I should have required a similar receipt to this from him on his return.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What was the nature of the business he had to do? A. To pack black-lead at my house—it was piece-work—I paid him every Saturday night—the course was to make out an account for the work he had done in the week.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had he any right to appropriate this money for wages? A. No; he brought his bill in every Saturday night, and was paid.

JAMES MARCH . The prisoner came to me, on the 11th of March, and brought an order from his master, in consequence of which I delivered him 15,000 labels—I did not receive any money from him fort hem—I knew him as the servant of Mr. Oakley, as he had been before—the upper part of this bill is mine, "15,000 bills, 18s. 9d." but this "Paid, J. March," is not mine, nor did I authorize anybody to write it.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe it was paid shortly afterwards? A. Yes, the prisoner called on the 4th of April, and paid it—he has been in the habit of getting things before on three or four occasions, and on one occasion he paid for some goods which he had had when he gave orders for others.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 3 7.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined

1223.
FRANCIS BANES was indicted
for embezzling 10d., the monies of
Thomas Griffin, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1224.
JAMES DAVISON was indicted
for stealing 2 3/4 yards of oilcloth value 8s. 6d., the goods of
John Lebrun; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months.

1225.
JAMES YALLOP was indicted
for stealing 1 loaf of bread, value 6d.; and 41bs. weight of flour, 7d.; the goods of
William Bush, his master.

WILLIAM BUSH . I live in York-row, Walworth. In 1843 I carried on the business of a baker—I ceased to do so on the 31st of Dec. 1844.—I was brought up a farmer—the prisoner came into my service in 1843—he was to bake bread for me—it was part of his duty to carry out bread to my customers, but not without my leave—he had a guinea a-week, and a quartern of bread a-day, and a quartern of flour on Saturday nights—he continued in my service till the 25th of April, 1844—he never had his

bread before six o'clock on other nights, and from eight till ten on Satur
day nights—on other'nights he left work a little after six, and on Saturday nights at ten—the bread he had was stale, and he had the flour on Saturday nights, from eight till ten o'clock, in a bag with my name marked on it—he generally had a baking of his own on Sundays, and always a batter-pudding under the meat—the bag that he had the flour I in on Saturday night was produced on Sunday over the meat—Mrs. Hunt made a communication to me, in consequence of which the prisoner was given into custody—I did not allow him a halfpenny a loaf on bread that he sold—I never gave him permission to open accounts with persons without my leave—I was not aware that any bread was being supplied to Mrs. Hunt—the prisoner left my service on the 25th of April, 1844—a day or two afterwards I found four quarterns of bread in a pump, mildewed—I had no other servant.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You were utterly surprised at Mrs. Hunt's information? A. I did not suspect anything of the kind—the prisoner lived with me about eight months—I do not know that he had been a master baker—I have heard say so—I gave him no right at all to sell any bread to Mrs. Hunt.

MARTHA HUNT . I am the wife of Edward Hunt. We live in George-street—I have known the prisoner about nine yean—in the beginning of Sept., 1843, he said Mr. Bush allowed him a halfpenny a loaf for the bread he sold, which made it better for Mr. Bush and for him, and he asked us to take bread of him—my husband said it did not matter who he had hit bread of, as he paid for it—we had not dealt with Mr. Bush before, nor did we know him—from that time we dealt with the prisoner—we had sometimes a quartern and a half of bread in a day, some
times less, about six or seven loaves in a week—I took more on a Saturday than other days—I always had new bread—he brought the bread in a morning, and on Satur
day, between four and five o'clock, he brought a quartern of flour—he continued to supply me from Sept. till the 26th of April following—these are the bills—on the 13th of April here is a charge for a loaf of bread and a quartern of flour—I had them of the prisoner—for about the first three weeks I paid for the bread and things as I had them—the prisoner then wished me to discontinue it—he said it would serve Mr. Bush, and he would have the overplus for himself—from the time I began to deal with him till I ceased, I never saw Mr. Bush—I paid the prisoner on account 1l., and 3s., and 8s., and 3s. again—last Friday week the prisoner had summoned my husband to the Court of Requests—I had not the money to pay it, and I went to Mr. Bush to see if I could talk to him to inter
cede with the prisoner to get time—the prisoner had summoned us in his own name.

Cross-examined. Q. There is an execution out against your husband, is there not? A. There is—I had known the prisoner nine years—he had been our tenant, and lived next door but one to us all the time this was going on—I have paid him three sums on this account since he left Mr. Bush—the rest he summoned us for—my husband went before the Com
missioners, and they ordered execution—I then went to Mr. Bush to intercede with the prisoner—my husband is not out of the way—our house is not shut up—they have not been trying to take our goods under the execution—they have not issued process—our door is not kept shut—I
did not go up to the Court—the bread was brought stale once or twice not more.

MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Is your husband here? A. Yes—the floury brought in a bag on Saturdays between four and five o'clock—the bag on left with the flour—the name of William Bush, and a bunch of wheat was on it—a quartern of flour was brought—the prisoner left these bills him
self—I saw him write when I gave him the sovereign.

WILLIAM MORTON (police-constable P 289.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 29th of April—I told him he was taken on a charge of felony on account of Mr. Bush—he said, "A charge of felony! I will soon settle that."

WILLIAM TROUGHT . I live in East-lane, Walworth, and am a green-grocer—I have known the prisoner for years—he has been a baker—I was a baker in 1843 and 1844—I supplied him with bread from the 11th of Sept. till the 23rd of April, 1844—I allowed him a halfpenny a loaf profit—I have supplied him, according to my recollection, with a couple of French loaves and a quartern of flour a week, which I left at his bout—it was on such terms as would enable him to sell it—it is a general custom of bakers to give their men bread—the prisoner has children that are bakers.

COURT. Q. Do you know Mrs. Hunt? A. No—I have heard she lives in George-street—she did not live nearer to me than to Mr. Bush, but it would be handier for her to get a supply from me—I served two customers in the same street.

JOHN STANFIELD . I live in Earl-street, London-road, and am a baker—I have supplied the prisoner as a baker during 1843 and 1844—I have frequently supplied him with bread in my rounds, sometimes four times a week.

COURT. Q. What do you mean by your rounds? A. I mean my bat where I go round to my customers—he was employed within the limits of my rounds—when he was first in the employ, he met me and asked me several times whether I could let him have a few loaves, and I let bin have it at a price to sell it again—he might get a penny a loaf, but always a halfpenny—a halfpenny is what we allow to persons we know nothing of to sell again, but, knowing him, I would willingly allow him a penny a loaf.

MR. CHARNOCK. Q. When did this supply take place? A. It began about this time two years as near as I can guess—I have no books here—I wanted no books, it was ready money—we never book it—I supply customers near to the prosecutor four times a week, on Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday—I met the prisoner several times, and he took a few loaves—I should say he had about two loaves a week.
NOT GUILTY .

1226.
JAMES YALLOP was again indicted
for stealing 41bs. weight of dough, value 7d., the goods of
William Bush, his master.
No Evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1227.
JAMES YALLOP was again indicted
for embezzling.
No Evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1228.
KEZIAH EDWARDS and
DANIEL SULLIVAN
were in
dicted for stealing 1 half-crown, 14 shillings, and 6 sixpences, the monies of John Rogers, from his person.

JOHN ROGERS . I keep a beer-shop in Red Cross-street. I had a booth at Wandsworth Fair—on the evening of the 13th of May, about ten o'clock* both the prisoners were in my booth—Sullivan asked me for a pint of beer, which he paid for—he had had four pints in the day, which he had not paid for—I gave him some meat, and Edwards some bread and cheese—she said she was Sullivan's cousin, and where he went she would go, but the would rather he would stay there, as he was tipsy, which he did—at eleven o'clock the officers came round and turned all out—the prisoners came in again about twelve, and Sullivan laid on a place about eight feet from me—Edwards said she would sit up all night—I then went to sleep on my left side, having in my watch-pocket 25s. in silver, amongst which was a new half-crown and a remarkable sixpence—about half-past six o'clock the policeman came and awoke me, to let him have a pint of beer—I got up and drew it—I laid down again, and when I awoke again I found part of my money was gone, and Sullivan was gone—he was there when I went to sleep, after serving the policeman—Edwards was in the booth—I taxed her with it—she said she knew nothing about it, but after a good while she said it might be Sullivan, for she had found the blade of a razor, and he had said to her, "Give me that, and I am off"—6s. 6d. was afterwards found on Sullivan in my presence—among it was a new half-crown, which was similar to the one I had had in my pocket, and this sixpence now produced, which I can swear to.
WILLIAM STONE (police-constable V 237.) I searched Edwards—I found nothing on her but a halfpenny, a knife, and fork.
GEORGE GRIFFITHS , (police-constable M 126.) I apprehended Sullivan in the course of the day, in a public-house—I found 6s. 6d. on him, and this half-crown and this sixpence amongst it.

SULLIVAN'S DEFENCE . I was drinking all night, and knew nothing about it; I laid down, and in the morning I was called to go to London; I was at work the day before, and earned half-a-crown, and the day before 3s.
Edwards's Defence. I went and had tome bread and cheese; I know nothing about this man.

EDWARDS—
NOT GUILTY .

SULLIVAN—
GUILTY .**—
Transported for Ten Years.

1229.
KEZIAH EDWARDS was again indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 4s.; the goods of
Mary Ann Haggerstone; to which the pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1230.
LEONARD GEORGE PROVO was indicted
for stealing 1 cask, value 10s.; and 25 gallons of vinegar, 32., the goods of
Frederick Colling-ridge, his master.

ALEXANDER DAVIS . I am in partnership with Mr. Frederick Collingridge; we are vinegar manufacturers, and live at Camberwell. The prisoner was in our service as town traveller since last May—his salary was 3l. per week—he was to go about collecting orders, and to hand me or my partner a list of them, with their residences—on the morning of the 2nd of April he

handed me this list of customers and their orders—here is in it the name of Thomas East, Goldsmith-row, Hackney-road, half a hogshead of 22 vine
gar—we designate the quality of the vinegar by numbers, from 16 to 24—this was well known to the prisoner—the price of this vinegar to East would be about 3l., and 10s. the cask—he had no authority to sell it for a less price than that—I handed the list to my partner, that it might be executed.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When an article was delivered out of your warehouse on an order of this kind, did you book the order to the prisoner? A. We book it to the party we deliver it to, not to the prisoner—we did not hold the prisoner responsible for the amount in any way—he did not receive any commission on sales—we took him on com
mission in May, but in Nov., from some circumstances, we found it right to alter the plan, and to give him 3l. a-week instead of commission—he received his 3l. every Saturday night—we began that in the early part of Dec.—we have paid him nothing in commission since that—the commis
sion he had from May to Nov. was fifteen per cent.—I will swear he was not to have ten per cent after that—the arrangement was made by myself and partner—there was an arrangement that if the commission on his sales would have exceeded 156l. per year he was to have it made up in commis
sion, but his sales were far less than that—there was no time named when we were to ascertain whether his sales had or had not exceeded 156l.—we did not contemplate any time, considering that he would hardly make it to the amount—if he had, he would have been entitled to a commission of fifteen per cent on the excess of sales—this order was for Thomas East, Goldsmith-row, Hackney-road, and I presume our carman found Mr. East at that direction—I was at the police-court—Mr. Price attended from Messrs. Potter and Collingridge as our solicitor—he called Mr. East, on the part of the prosecution, but he varied much from what he stated to me in the first instance—there have repeatedly been complaints made of orden having been obtained by the prisoner, and the persons afterwards refusing to take the goods—I have blamed the prisoner for it exceedingly—we never told him to the effect that if it happened again he should be at the cost of the articles, nor conveyed that to him—we blamed him for getting fictitious orders when the people would not take them in, and he had not seen the people—we took him last May—we exacted security from him to the amount of 300l.

Q. Did you receive securities from him to the amount of at least 800l.? A. Decidedly, from inquiry they are not worth that—I should think 300l. was the outside of the value of them—I believe they were papers connected with his wife's property, but I have not seen them—they are in the possession of Potter and Collingridge—they made out the deed—I cannot say personally that I have ever seen that deed—my partner has—I have been told he has been obliged to effect a life assurance to the amount of 200l.—I have not seen it—very likely my partner has it—I know the prisoner pays an insurance, which is to keep us secure against any defalcation of his—we have been applied to by the prisoner or his solicitor for a statement of our account, pro and con.—we have not given it, and I can give you a reason why—after the charge was made against the prisoner, East went at nine o'clock one night to our foreman's wife—I did not see him, but I received a communication from our foreman, who is not here—I have not the least doubt that East offered the money—when we took the prisoner, he had a connexion—he has done a very good trade

for us, and has increased our business considerably—he brought his con
nexion with him, and may have obtained us sales to the amount of 1000l. a-year—that is quite the outside—I state that from recollection—we know all his connexions now—we have employed a party in his stead, and at the same salary—we do not mean to give up his connexion now we have got it—six months is the usual credit we give to our customers.

MR. DOANX. Q. Why did you not give an account to the prisoner? A. Because we are daily finding he has received money and not accounted for it—we did not threaten to discharge him with respect to those gales where the orders were not met.

FREDERICK COLLINGRIDGE . I am partner with Mr. Davies. I re
member receiving this list, (looking at it,) and, in consequence, I gave instructions to one of our carmen to take this vinegar to Mr. East's, in Goldsmith's-row—it was sent on the 3rd of April—it came to 3l. 10s.—I made an invoice out to East—it went between nine and ten o'clock in the morning—it is four or five miles from our factory to Goldsmith's-row—in consequence of what I heard, I went to Barking on the 14th of April—I there found a half-hogshead, marked "No. 22," in possession of a man named Stevens, who had never had any dealings with us to my knowledge—our name was branded on the cask.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Mrs. East? A. I do—I am not aware that I said to her that I did not care about the money for the vinegar—to the best of my recollection, I did not say anything about it.

Q. Did you say if it cost 300l. you did not care, if you could get a con
viction against Provo? A. The words I used were," He deserves to go to the Old Bailey for this"—I did not use the word "conviction" to Mrs. East, to the best of my belief—I swear I did not—we took the prisoner on a verbal contract, as far as my recollection serves;—I really cannot say—it is a year ago—we have securities in the hands of our solicitor—I do not know to what amount—I believe they are to the amount of 250l. or 300l.—we have not given directions to our solicitor to hand them over to the pri
soner, that they might not be lost in case of a conviction—I am not ac
quainted with law—I am the brother of Mr. Collingridge—I have given directions not to give the securities up, because we have found out other defalcations—we have not obtained another bill—I think the Magistrate remanded the prisoner three times—I believe he was taken on Sun
day evening, the 20th of April, and was examined on Monday, the 21st, then remanded, I think for a week; and then, I think, from the Monday till the Tuesday week, and since then I suppose he has been in Newgate—we preferred this charge on the day he was apprehended.
MR. DOANE. Q. Was not the prisoner taken upon the 4th of May? A. Yes, it was, I had forgotten it—we had a verbal contract with the prisoner last December to pay him 8l. a week.

LOUISA EAST . I am the wife of Charles East—we live in Goldsmith's-row, Hackney-road—my husband keeps a broker's shop. I remember half a hogshead of vinegar coming to ray husband about twelve o'clock in the morning, on the 3rd of April—I was not aware whose cart it came in—I signed the receipt in the book for the cask—this is the receipt I gave—my husband was out at the time—I did not expect a cask of vinegar—I saw the prisoner in the course of that day—he asked me for the invoice. of the vinegar, and I gave it him—a man named Hallett took away the vinegar—I knew Hallett, but I bad said nothing about him to anybody——I

did not refer the prisoner to a carman—nothing was said about one—Hallett is a carman—he came and took away the vinegar about one o'clock—my husband did not see the cask, he did not come home till about ten o'clock at night.

Cross-examined. Q. What is your husband carrying on now? A. The business of a broker—he has been doing so only a few months—before that he kept a shop in the general line where we now live—we dealt in vinegar at that time, and had given the prisoner one or two orders—my husband has been living in that neighbourhood about twelve years, and twelve months in our present house—Mr. Collingridge, the prosecutor, came to me three or four times—he first came to know something about us, but I cannot tell what.

Q. Did he say he did not care about the money for the vinegar; if it cost 300l. he did not care, all he wanted was to get a conviction against Provo? A. He never made use of the word "conviction"—he said it was not the money he cared for, if it was 300l. he would rather lose it than not have the case against him—I think they were the words—I never had any charge against myself—I am not a particular friend of the prisoner's—I do not think I saw him above half a dozen of times—I have no family.
COURT. Q. You had had dealings with him before? A. We had two casks, whether they were together I do not know—the prisoner knew my husband.

GEORGE HALLETT . I live in Dove-row, and am a fishmonger. I have a horse and cart, which I generally go with myself—I never knew the prisoner before this—he came to me, and hired my cart for a little job—I cannot say the time exactly—I went myself with it—he told me to go to East's, in Goldsmith's-row, which is four or five yards from my place—it was about one o'clock—he was to give me 1s. 6d. for the job—I was to take the cart to Spitalfields church, and meet him there—I saw Mrs. East at her own place—I took the half-hogshead from East's to Spitalfields church—the prisoner was not there, but he came soon afterwards—he said, "Follow me," and he took me to Widegate-alley, and there, by his direc
tion, I rolled out the half-hogshead to Mr. Sandifer's shop—it remained outside the door—the prisoner told me to go back to Mr. East's, where he would meet me and pay me—I went there—he did not come, and I new saw him till he was in custody—I saw Mr. Sandifer at the door of his shop—I did not speak to him.

ROBERT SANDIFER . I am an oilman, and live in Artillery-passage, Wide
gate-alley. On the 3rd of April the prisoner came to my shop about ten or eleven o'clock in the morning, as near as I can recollect—he said he bad half a hogshead of vinegar to dispose of—I said, "I am not a buyer of vinegar; vinegars are so low, it is useless for me to lay out money for vinegar"—whether he said it was returned on his hands, or he had it to dispose of, I really cannot recollect—I agreed to buy it—he asked me 30s. for it—I said, "I will give you 25s., I won't give you a farthing more"—he said, "If I can't get more I must take that"—he brought me the vinegar between one and two, or about two o'clock—I did not see the carman—I tasted the vinegar, to see that I had vinegar—there was 22 marked on the cask—I gave him 25s.—he gave me this bill and receipt for the money I paid him: "Mr. Sandifer bought of John Emmett, goods 1l. 5s., Settled"—he wrote this in my presence—I did not know anything about him—I recollect since I had some slight knowledge of his features—I did not

know where he lived, or where I could find him—I kept the vinegar eight or nine days, and then sold it to a Mr. Stevens for 30s.—neither I nor Mr. Stevens could recognize the name on the cask, it was so imperfectly branded.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know what the "22" indicates on the cask of vinegar? A. It indicates, if we have it from respectable houses, that it is 22 strong—the 22 is frequently marked on something under 22, that we may not show we are selling 16 vinegar we put 22 on it—I have it from respectable houses—I never buy of cheap houses—I spiled it and showed the vinegar to Mr. Stevens—I had nothing to test the strength of it.

WILLIAM HENRY STEVENS . I am a grocer and cheesemonger, and live at Barking, in Essex. About the 11th of April I bought this half-hogshead of vinegar of Mr. Sandifer for 30s., in a regular way of business—it was found at my place.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it worth more than 30s.? A. A regular vinegar-house traveller called on me, and I told him what I gave for this, and I bought a 20 vinegar better than this was—I am not a judge, but according to my judgment, I did not consider it anything like the quality—there was a name on the cask.

THOMAS PRITCHARD (police-constable P 22.) I was looking out for the prisoner at the latter end of April—he was taken on Sunday, the 4th of May, at his own house—I told him it was on a charge of stealing a cask of vinegar from Collingridge and Davis—he said he could explain the matter, he had received an order from Mr. East, of Goldsmith-row, when it was sent there Mr. East did not want it, he had then bought it of Mr. East, and sold it to Mr. Sandifer.
COURT to LOUISA EAST. Q. What name does your husband go by? A. He is generally known by the name of Thomas.
NOT GUILTY .

1231.
JOHN KING was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining 36 yards of linen cloth, value 2l. 11s. 8d., the goods of
Richard Breman, by false pretences.

RICHARD BREMAN . I am a linen-draper, and live at Wandsworth. On the 28th of March the prisoner came to me, and said he had been sent by Mrs. Rote the butcher for twenty-eight yards of linen-cloth—I believed he came from her, and let him have twenty-eight yards of linen-cloth, which came to 2l. 11s. 8d.

ANN ROTE . I am a butcher, and live in Larkhall-lane—I did not send the prisoner for any goods to Mr. Brenam, nor did I receive the pro
perty—I did not know the prisoner.

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

1232.
PATRICK MURRY was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Isa
bella Martin, with intent, &c.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY THE 16TH OF JUNE.
